headline: Bread Machine Thin Crust Pizza Dough
description: This bread machine pizza dough recipe is made with just a few basic pantry ingredients for a large, flavorsome, and chewy pizza crust.
name: Bread Machine Thin Crust Pizza Dough
recipeIngredient: 0.75 cup warm water - 100 to 110 degrees F (40 to 45 degrees C)

recipeInstructions.text: Pour warm water into the bread machine pan; add flour on top of water. Sprinkle over yeast, salt, and sugar. Set the machine on the dough setting, and push the start button. When the machine signals that the dough is finished, transfer dough to a well-floured work surface.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
Roll or stretch dough out into a thin crust about 14 inches in diameter, leaving dough thick at the edge. Place dough onto a 14-inch pizza baking sheet; brush dough with olive oil.
Bake in the preheated oven for 5 minutes; remove and top with desired ingredients before final baking.

review.reviewBody: Made it. super easy and my husband loved it I added Italian seasoning to the dough

DH and I have been on a mission to find The Recipe for thin crust pizza dough. This made a real great thin, crispy crust, which surprised me because it's the first recipe we tried without any oil! In the past, adding more oil seemed to make a better thin crust so I was skeptical, but we made the recipe as written. We did divide it in half and refrigerate it overnight, set it out at room temp for 30 minutes and it was soooo easy to work with. Rolled out half the recipe to about 12 inches with oiled surface and rolling pin, then brushed and baked as directed in the recipe and my dh declared this is it!! This is the holy grail thin and crispy on the bottom with a little chew! Really great recipe Healthy Boy! Thanks! BTW, we refrigerated it before the rise time in the bread maker.
Very good. Dough was easy to work with. I will be making again.
This is perfect every time!

I've been using a "regular" crust recipe for years, but wanted to make a thin crust pizza. I followed the recipe, but did add some seasonings per other comments (about 1/2 Tbs garlic powder, parmesan cheese & Italian seasoning). The dough was very sticky, so I used a lot of flour when shaping the pie. I wanted to cook it directly on my pizza stone, but it was too thin and sticky to transfer. So I pressed it into shape on a pizza pan and put that on the stone. I baked it for about 5 minutes, then took it out to put on the sauce, cheese and toppings. It was delicious! Will make this again.

This is a very dependable, easy recipe - works great. I'd highly recommend.
Only thing is it could use a better picture at the top of the recipe, :-)
It is a great recipe, worked out for my cookie sheet. Nice soft pliable dough.
Not quite as thin n crispy as I would like but I believe it was my fault. Still very good. I will definitely make this again with a couple of suggestions from the reviews.

Do yourself a big favor and go to a specialty grocery story and find “Tipo 00” or double 0 extra fine grade flour. The store where I found it had Italian brands offering this grade of flour. It’s the secret ingredient you need to know about. It adds a wonderful crispy yet chewy texture that is superior to the results I got with all purpose flour.
This my 2nd time making it and I LOVE IT. So easy to make and work with

I use this recipe weekly, never changing a thing. it's the perfect crust in my opinion. I roll it out on a greased pizza pan with a little cornmeal already sprinkled on it, and prebake it at 425 for maybe 10 minutes. then add the toppings and cook 15 minutes more or until golden brown, I like mine a little crispier

This worked for us. I split it into 2 thin and crispy pizza crusts. I also added the garlic to the crust like many others. We used a cast iron pizza pan and heated the pan first and cooked the dough 5-7 min prior to toppings. It took about 45 min in my bread machine. We will be making more to freeze and use at a later time.
My go to crust when short on time. Wonderfully chewy without a lot of time or work.

Amazing recipe! My first ever pizza came put very well. I rolled it out and used a pizza pan, but forgot to cook the base before putting the other ingredients on. Simple to fix - I just waited until the base was sturdy enough then removed it from the pan and laid it directly on an oven grill for the last 5 minutes. It came out beautifully!
This crust turned out to be the best thin crust pizza I have made. Very crispy and tasty. You do have to be patient and allow the crust to start to brown before removing from the oven.
Super easy and turned out great. I’ve made it several times now. I’ve found that if I double the recipe, it makes 4 individual size pizzas. We cook our pizzas on the Green Egg and they are delicious!

I have made this crust 5 times. It has been perfect each time!!
I added 2T Italian seasoning and 1T garlic powder.
Made 2 small pizzas, perfect portion for 2 adults and 2 to

Taste was good. Mine turned out as tough as shoe leather. Tried it again, left it in covered bowl overnight in fridge. Same result. Still searching for a light crispy pizza dough for my bread machine.

This is the recipe I have been looking for! I made it with half all purpose and half whole wheat flour. Needed to add a little water during the mixing phase to get the dough to come together. Turned out great.
No changes and we loved it

Just yum! I added Parmesan, Italian spices and garlic. Toppings were portobello mushrooms, sausage, hamburger and onion. Mozzarella cheese of course. Baked 5 minutes on preheated stone. Added toppings and baked another 15 minutes at 425. Came out perfect! Thank you!
Hey out there I love this recipe!
Great crust, I did add a little garlic powder to the dough.
I made it exactly and it was good.. pizza dough has to be rolled out and stretched but that’s usual to make it nice and thin!

This really did turn out great according to recipe directions. Instead of baking it immediately, I formed it to the pan and froze it. Now, I have a stack of frozen pizza crust in the freezer ready to enjoy 'whenever'!

I used gold medal bread flour instead of AP flour. before brushing on the olive oil poke the crust with a fork and make dimples with your fingertips. after putting on the oil sprinkle course salt and pepper, Italian seasoning, and garlic and onion powders. Bake as recommended. Top with your favorites and bake in the oven as high as it will go on a pizza pan covered in corn meal. It should take 10-15 minutes to bake depending on your toppings and your oven.
This recipe was awesome! The whole family loved it. Even the kids!

Just as promised; thin yet with a nice chewy texture. The recipe doesn't specify a cooking time after adding toppings. We set the timer for 20 minutes, but it was done nicely in 15 or 16. Will make again, but double the recipe for our family of six. (I did the one pound .)
Loved it!
Very nice, will make again!
perfect
I've used this recipe for years....perfect every time!
It was ok, definitely was not crispy for us. Would not make again using this recipe.

I used brown sugar instead of white, and I used bread flour instead of all purpose. I used an iron skillet because I don't have a pizza stone, it works pretty well for crisping the crust if you preheat it same as a stone. Just have to be careful putting the dough in so you don't get burned. This turned out perfectly. Thanks.

Now that is a great pizza dough! Easy to make and very good tasting. First time I used my bread machine for pizza dough. Makes a nice thin crust. I LOVE thin crust pizza. Put roasted garlic powder and Italian seasoning and grated Parmesan on the crust before baking. The edge came out nice and crunchy. Will use this dough for Calzone too. Have to make 2 next time and freeze one.
Added some garlic powder and Italian seasoning to the recipe. Was delicious.
Followed recipe exactly and used bobs red mill bread flour. The crust was great! Fresh, simple, and crispy!
Easy recipe...added fresh chopped rosemary. ..very tasty. ..will definitely make again

Made a few modifications, replaced water with flat beer added 1/2 tsp each of garlic powder, basil and oregano and reduced yeast to 3/4 tsp and as others have doubled the recipe and prebake the crust in single serve pizza’s and freeze for quick pizza whenever you want! Great flavor and rolled out thin enough will actually make a thin crust pizza! ENJOY
Great pizza crust. I used with a rectangle pan and it was perfect.

This was my first time making pizza crust. It turned out better then expected. I followed the directions except added a little garlic. I only made a cheese pizza for my trial run. I'll be making this again and adding more toppings. Perfect for a simple girl like me.

I used my Pampered Chef pizza stone and had it preheated in the 500 degree oven. I was able to make 2 pizza crusts from this recipe. I baked the crust plain for 2 minutes; then added my toppings and baked for additional 5 minutes. This was a tasty, crackery crust, as I was hoping for. It was divine and I will definitely make it again!

I made this the other night. Very tasty. It didn’t crisp up like I thought it would. Perhaps the first 5 minutes in the oven should be a bit longer (I didn’t take altitude into account). I will definitely use this recipe again!
I used whey instead of the water in the recipe. My pizza had some homemade cheese on it. The crust was perfect!

Awesome pizzeria crust! I've made this several times. I like to sub a little whole wheat flour for part of the flour in the recipe. I typically make the dough the day or a few days before baking and store in a ziploc bag in the refrigerator. Then I roll out the dough on a little corn meal mixed with flour and pre-bake on a perforated pan for just a couple minutes before adding the toppings. Great non-soggy texture! Bake at a high temp - 450 or higher, for best results.
This has been my go-to pizza dough for quite a while now. Very easy and turns out great!

Came out awesome. I did not brush with olive oil. I did add approximately 1 tsp of corn meal in bread machine with flour. And I did not pre-bake it. I added toppings and put in a 425° oven for 14 minutes. I used an 18" pizza pan and it stretched perfectly with no sticking. Super thin and crispy yet light.
Really easy and has a nice, chewy texture. The whole family loved it. This is my go-to crust from now on!
I won't be using this again, as the dough ended up very tough to chew. I've made pizza for many years, so not a newbie to it. It is, indeed, easy to make. But not what I was looking for.
Great recipe. It made 1 very large pizza and very tasty. I will definitely use it again in the future.
I made this pizza it was the best .I have made others but this was the best .I put parmesan cheese & oregano in the dough it was the best I ever made & I used whole wheat flour I would make it again.
Easy and delicious. Also great for making Calzones
We liked it, doubled recipe for 2 pizzas and used 4 tsp yeast.

Love this recipe! My third pizza using this recipe is in my machine now. I used Italian flour (Antimo Caputo) which is available at Walmart and it worked better than my usual AP flour. I followed the recipe as written but didn't use heated water, as the bread machine heats it. Used a wooden pizza peel with parchment paper on top. The dough with olive oil on top was easy to spread into a large pizza size. Prebaked the crust for 5 minutes then added the toppings. The parchment paper under the pizza made it easy to slide onto the pizza stone and take the finished pizza out. Parchment paper takes the high temps fine and saves the pizza from ending up all over the oven racks! Crust was crisp and delicious!
was quick easy and tasted great

Direction didn't specify how long to bake after toppings are added. This is our fist time making pizza dough with our bread maker. I made two pizzas with the dough. One in a heart shaped pan and he other in a 12" pizza pan. The heart shaped one was baked with sauce and cheese for 10 mins. The round one was pre baked 5 min. topped with sauce, cheese and red bell peppers and baked another 7 min. The heart shaped one was more like a hand tossed pizza and the round I was able to stretch thinner and it turned out thin and crispy. We like it, but it's not exactly like the pizzeria.
This made the best pizza I have been able to turn out in years. Really crisp in a home oven. That doesn't happen very often.

Easy and delicious!

I rolled pepperoni and string cheese into the edges of the crust.

Nice Crust. Made according to recipe. 

The key to good dough is adjusting the moisture content of the dough while the dough is kneading in the bread machine. Due to differences in flour, humidity, etc you can seldom make bread dough using the same exact measurements each time. About 5 minutes into the kneading cycle of the bread machine look at the dough. If it is too wet add flour a tablespoon at a time, giving the machine time to incorporate each addition, until you have the proper dough consistency. If the dough is too dry use the same procedure only adding water instead of flour. 

The dough consistency you are looking for is a soft ball that is slightly tacky. It will lightly stick to the side of the bread pan but pull off cleanly as the machine kneads it.

When the dough cycle is complete, transfer to a lightly floured surface and knead 6 or 8 times. Cover and allow to rest 10 minutes for the dough to relax. Put dough between 2 pieces of parchment paper and roll into a 14" to 15" circle. Transfer to a 15" or 16" pizza pan leaving the parchment on the bottom of the dough.

Precook the crust on the top shelf of your oven preheated to 450 degrees for 10 minutes and remove from oven. The crust will look like a little balloon. Poke holes on it with a fork and deflate it. Allow to cool until easy to handle and add your choice of toppings.

To finish cooking slide the pizza and parchment paper from the pan back onto the top rack of your preheated oven and then
Really excellent. If you are making individual pizzas I found that this recipe was sufficient for two pizzas. So for four persons double the quantities.
Made twice, like best with 1/2&1/2 Bread flour...really easy, really good...550° on Pizza stone
It's perfect!!!! I made two small pizzas instead of one big and they turned out great! The crust is perfect and both chewy and crunchy!
Great recipe! I added a little seasoning for my family's tastes, made a double batch in the bread machine, and made calzones so everyone could have what they wanted inside. Delicious!

I ended up having to roll the dough as it just kept ripping, I would have given it a 5 star but when it was cooked the underneath was slightly doughy, however I will be making it again and adding a few little tweaks ;-) all in all it went down well, kids loved it :-)
I made this in my bread machine and added 1/4 tsp of oregano, 1/4 tsp of basil, and 1 tsp of minced garlic. The flavor was delicious and the crust texture was really good!! Thanks for a great recipe!
Very tasty and easy!!! Crust was crunchy yet not cracker dry. Would make again.
My family loved it. We have not had luck with home made pizza crust. This is the first recipe that my family said we have to have again. Thank you!

I'm not sure what happened.. I made the recipe exactly as it was listed and it was a soupy watery mess. I had to add in more flour and it just made it rubbery tasting in the end. I would not recommend this recipe at all. This recipe probably needs bread flour instead of regular flour.
Good crunchy thin crust. I brushed olive oil on both sides of the crust, then added sauce, filling and cheese. Very good.
Very good pizza dough, easy to make and tasty. I added some dried basil (leftover from last year's garden), and a little garlic powder. Thanks for the quick and easy recipe!
This is a good recipe! I've made it about once a week for the past couple years. I've found it turns out better for me if I double the recipe.
Just the recipe we've been looking for in a thin crust! Crispy all the way through with great flavor!

This was my first attempt with the bread machine to make dough as well as to bake it on the pizza stone in the bbq. This was the best pizza and crust we have ever made. Followed the recipe as written, but I did as some others have, added some garlic powder, Italian Seasoning and Parmesan. We like our crust thin, so this actually made two crusts for us. Our pan is about 14 inches round. Wonderful
A great pizza dough, I added a few herbs into the machine and it cooked up perfect and I used a toaster oven .... it makes two 12 inch pizzas ...love it
I made this using a kitchen aid instead of a bread machine and turns out yummy every time
I made this using a kitchen aid instead of a bread machine and turns out yummy every time

I've made this pizza twice. First turned out perfectly.Second time I doubled it and it was very liquid almost like a cake batter. I fixed that by transferring it to my stand mixer and adding in flour until it was just right. I think adding Garlic salt is helpful.
added parm, oreg, and garlic powder, but still needed more spice, but all in all it was not bad, and very easy to work with. I also doubled recipe.
Good basic recipe to build off of.

Yum, yum, yum!!!! This recipe is simple and fantastic! The only change I made was to use garlic salt in place of plain salt. I don't have a pizza stone so I just used a large baking sheet. Baked the pizza w/o toppings for 5 minutes, added toppings and then baked again until brown and bubbly! I'm so happy to have finally found a great pizza dough recipe!
Easy to follow. Good, tasty recipe; nothing outstanding.

This crust is amazing. I made it in the kitchen aid instead of the breadmaker to save time. I mixed the sugar, warm water and yeast in the kitchen aid bowl for a few minutes until the yeast was foamy. Then I added the remaining ingredients and also added about a 1/2 tsp of garlic powder, a couple of pinches of oregano and Rosemary. Kneaded for about 2 minutes and let rise for about 30 minutes. I didn't precook and baked it for about 16 minutes. The texture was amazing, it was one of the best crusts I've made.

Didn't work at all in my bread machine. Resulted in many dried lumps of dough, even though I followed the recipe exactly.
Ok, tried again, used 2 TABLESPOONS of oil. A much better result.

Perfect restaurant quality crust. I followed the recipe exactly and baked it at 500 F on a pizza stone. This dough recipe is moist, very easy to work with and delicious. I followed other reviewers recommendation and added garlic powder to the olive oil in the par bake step.
Tried other pizza crust recipes and this one is my favorite. I've made it numerous times and always comes out great.
This is my go to pizza dough. Works great every time. Kids love it too. I have made the dough with spelt flour and wholewheat and been very happy with the results.

My husband likes a very crisp St. Louis style pizza, and this crust has been our favorite. I usually triple the recipe and make them up and freeze the crust after they are par baked for about 7-8 min. I have also left them in the fridge in balls to use later. Very easy go to recipe and wonderful predictable results

The other reviews are accurate about stating it tastes like a cheap thin crust. Reminded me of a frozen pizza. My two young boys did love it & that is why I rated it a 4 star. I was hoping for a crisp cracker crust vs a more dense bread crust. The dough came out perfect from the machine was stretchy & not sticky. In conclusion I would recommend this recipe as it seems it will work every time & is indeed edible, but not gourmet pizza crust & wont impress guests.

Love this recipe, quick, easy, and amazing with these additional steps: added garlic powder and oregano to the dough when mixing, added great flavor. also added a step with oil: oil a large bowl and ball of dough, tightly cover bowl in aluminum foil, and place in warmed oven (250 degrees then turn off heat) for about 20-30 min. lightly punch out air before rolling out the dough. Really allows the flavor to permeate the dough.

Very easy! I added Italian herb seasonings to the flour mixture. 
If the dough feels too wet add a little more flour. I have made this several times. I have used while wheat flour and done with all purpose flour.

Nice thin crust recipe. I made a couple of changes by adding one tsp of the olive oil into the bread machine and used one cup of all purpose flour, 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup of multi-grain flour. I love the grainy texture this adds to the crust.
Yum, this was a great crust. I had to add a bit more flour, it is extremely humid here right now, so it was a bit sticky at first. After the extra flour was added it was perfect.
Excellent recipe. Makes a beautiful crust.
this is the best pizza dough I've ever been able to make. Many thanks. Got the bread machine out of the "take to Goodwill"pile. Sorry Goodwill.
Came out really well. Delicious.
This was very easy for a first time bread dough maker. Dough is very easy to work with and turns out awesome. Thanks for sharing it.

My housemate asked me to make the pizza dough for the meal she was preparing. I made dough for three pizzas using this recipe. We had to put them in the frig to wait for her to make them. The pizzas turned out great and the dough was terrific.
It wasn't the thin crust that I was expecting it to be. It was good just not as crispy as I was hoping for.

item.name: Bread Machine Thin Crust Pizza Dough
